answers: "What is Enlightenment?" [or "Answering the Question: What is Enlightenment?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?"]
public AND private [or öffentliche AND privat]
parts: Name this essay which provides an answer to its title question by defining a certain movement as man's emergence from "self-incurred immaturity".
This philosopher from Königsberg wrote "What is Enlightenment," as well as the Critique of Pure Reason.

"What is Enlightenment" distinguishes between uses of reason denoted by these two terms, which respectively refer to use of reason as a scholar before the "world of readers" and in one's own vocation.
This meditation on death by William Cullen Bryant declares that "thou shalt lie down / With patriarchs of the infant world".
This poet's "Stanzas Written in Dejection, Near Naples" states "I could lie down, like a tired child...till death like sleep might steal on me". This author eulogized a fellow poet in "Adonais".

A passage of this book remarks that "since our longest sun sets at right declensions," it therefore "cannot be long before we lie down in darkness". This book describes man as a "Noble Animal, splendid in ashes, and pompous in the grave" and was paired with the author’s The Garden of Cyrus.
Name this statement used in the derivation of the Sackur-Tetrode equation due to the indistinguishability of gas particles.
Stirling's formula approximates this function. For N distinct particles, the number of permutations is this function of N.
An N factorial term also appears when computing this quantity for multi-particle systems. This quantity is the normalization constant for the Boltzmann distribution.

answers: Light Verse [or Verse of Light; or Ayah an-Nur; or Ayat an-Nur; accept Quran 24:35]
al-Ghazali [or Abū Ḥāmid Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad aṭ-Ṭūsiyy al-Ġaz(z)ālīy; accept Algazelus]
parts: Name this famously esoteric verse of the Qur'an that compares God to an object in a niche. A phrase from this verse is often used to describe God's infinite beauty and guidance.

This Islamic scholar's commentary The Niche of Lights considers three types of light and says that the only true light is God, who is pure light. He promoted occasionalism in a treatise attacking Aristotelian philosophy.
The Light Verse is particularly popular in this mystical Islamic tradition, which holds that all things were created from light.

answers: (Joannes) Leo Africanus [or Hasan Ibn Muhammad al-Wazzan]
Askia Muhammad I [or Askia the Great; or Muhammad Ture]
parts: Name this empire which displaced the Mali empire in the 15th century under such leaders as Sonni Ali Ber. It had its capital at Gao (rhymes with "cow").

Much of what we know today about the Songhai's conquest of Hausaland comes from this Berber historian, who was captured by Christian pirates in 1518. John Pory translated this historian's Geographical History of Africa into English.
The Songhai empire reached its greatest extent under this leader. He established qadis, or judges, in every Songhai city, and is buried beneath a mud brick pyramid in Gao.

answers: William Tell [accept Guillaume Tell; or Guglielmo Tell]
parts: Name this composer who unusually included twelve singers, two pianos, and a harmonium in his late Petite messe solennelle ("peh-TEET mess soh-leh-NELL").
Rossini only published a few pieces in the years after this opera, whose overture calls for flute and English horn in its Ranz des vaches and ends with a "March of the Swiss Soldiers".

In the last 11 years of his life, Rossini compiled 150 pieces into his Péchés de vieillesse ("peh-SHEH de vee-ay-YEZ"), some of which were arranged into this composer's Rossiniana. This Italian also wrote Ancient Airs and Dances.

answers: dogs [accept The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time]
parts: Name this Greek text which inspired the play Father Comes Home From the Wars. That play's protagonist takes on the name Ulysses in reference to this text's protagonist.

Amusingly, Father Comes Home From the Wars features one of these animals named "Odd-See". A 2012 Simon Stephens play about Christopher Boone titled for one of these animals won seven Laurence Olivier awards.
Father Comes Home From the Wars is by this playwright, who won the 2002 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for a play about Booth and Lincoln, the latter of whom works as an Abraham Lincoln impersonator.
As part of the Gleneagles Agreement, heads-of-states from this organization agreed to discourage sporting events with South Africa. This organization mostly consists of former British colonies.
29 countries boycotted the Olympics of this year because New Zealand's rugby team had toured South Africa. Four years later, the U.S. would boycott the Moscow Olympics.
This New Zealand prime minister controversially allowed the 1981 Springbok tour to occur. This prime minister began large-scale infrastructure spending as part of the "Think Big" strategy.

answers: sparse matrix [accept word forms such as sparseness]
parts: Breadth-first search is contrasted with this type of search, which explores a branch all the way to the end before backtracking.
Breadth-first search can check if a graph has no odd length cycles, which implies this property. Graphs with this property have perfect matchings, which means that they are 2-colorable.

The Cuthill-McKee algorithm uses breadth-first search to permute a matrix that is both symmetric and has this property into a "band" form. Large matrices with this property can be stored compactly in the triplet representation.

answers: Andre Gregory [prompt on My Dinner With Andre]
parts: One of this director's final works was 1990's Ganashatru ("GONE-ah-SHAH-thru"), an adaptation of Ibsen's An Enemy of The People. A brother and sister witness a train passing by a crop field in an iconic scene from this director’s Pather Panchali (“puh-THERE pun-CHAH-lee”),

For a 2013 adaptation of The Master Builder, Jonathan Demme ("deh-ME") cast this French-born actor and theater director in the role of Knut Brovik. In another film, this actor meets with a character played by Wallace Shawn in the Café des Artistes.
This actor starred as Torvald Helmer in a 1973 film adaptation of A Doll's House and starred as Dr. Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs.

answers: Finlandization [or suomettuminen; or Finnlandisierung; or Finlandizatsiya; do not prompt or accept "Finland"]
West Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany or Bundesrepublic Deutschland; prompt on Germany or Deutschland]
parts: Give this term describing the domination of the politics of a small country by a larger neighbor. It originally referred to relations between the Soviet Union and the country it once fought in the Winter War.
The term "Finlandization" originated in debates in this country in the 1960s during the tenure of its SDP leader Willy Brandt ("VIL-ee bront").
The term was popularized by this hardline anti-Communist German political scientist, who lends his name to a 1950s-era policy of trying to isolate East Germany diplomatically.

answers: Janus AND Vesta [accept in either order; accept Janus primus, Vesta extrema; prompt on partial answers; accept "De Janus à Vesta" or "From Janus to Vesta"]
crossroads [prompt on intersections, roads, or clear equivalents of either]
parts: Name these two liminal deities who were invoked first and last in Roman rituals. They were also the protectors of weddings.
The Compitalia festival honored Mania and some lares ("LAIR-eez") of these other liminal places. These places were considered gates to the underworld and sacred to the goddess Trivia.
Since both were liminal gods worshiped at crossroads, Romans identified Odin with this psychopomp and father of the lares who carried messages between gods and humans.

answers: Parkinson's disease [or idiopathic parkinsonism; or primary parkinsonism; or hypokinetic rigid syndrome; or HRS; or paralysis agitans]
parts: Name this neurologist who wrote about administering L-DOPA ("el-doh-pah") to patients in Awakenings, as well as The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat.
The chapter "Kinetic Melody" from Musicophilia describes using music to cure patients with this neurological disease, which results in loss of motor skills often manifested as shaking.

Another chapter of Musicophilia discusses children with this genetic disorder, who often develop great musical talent. Children with it typically develop speech abilities later than others and often suffer from hyperacusia ("hyper-ah-KYOO-zhuh").

answers: inner core [do not accept or prompt on "core" or "outer core"]
parts: Inge Lehmann discovered what layer of the Earth, which consists of a solid iron-nickel alloy?
In this phenomenon, heat flow from the inner core contributes to convection currents in the outer core, causing circulating electric currents which generate the Earth's magnetic field.
The inner core's super-rotation was first predicted in 1995 by this first self-consistent numerical model of the geodynamo, developed by two American scientists.

answers: How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia
parts: Bimala exits the role of a housewife to take part in the Swadeshi movement in this Bengali author's novel The Home and the World. He also wrote the poetry collection Gitanjali ("ghee-TAHN-juh-lee").

In this Aravind Adiga novel framed as a series of letters to Chinese premier Wen Jiabao ("j'yah-bao"), Balram leaves his village to become a chauffeur before moving to Bangalore to start a taxi business.
This Mohsin Hamid novel tells the reader to move to the city, start a water bottling business, get married, and have a son who moves to America in order to accomplish the title goal.
Name this African-American explorer who discussed his experiences on seven Arctic voyages in A Negro Explorer at the North Pole.
Henson accompanied this American explorer on his expedition to the North Pole in 1909. He reached Greenland's northernmost point, Cape Morris Jessup, on an earlier expedition.
Due to skepticism over Henson's voyage, the first undisputed expedition to the North Pole was led by this Norwegian explorer, the first to reach the South Pole and traverse the Northwest Passage.

answers: Lorraine (The three countries are Luxembourg, Belgium, and Germany.)
parts: This northeast region of France is the only French region to border three other countries. It was once part of a state with Alsace.

The Moselle river, which runs through the Lorraine region, names one of these units that is the most populous in Lorraine. France is itself divided into 96 of these administrative units, four of which are located in Lorraine.

This city, the most populous in the Lorraine region, is located at the confluence of the Moselle and Grand Seille ("grahn say") rivers. It is also home to a Georgia Tech campus, as well as a Shigeru Ban-designed Centre Pompidou.
Name this sculptor. This sculptor created a statue that shows a man pointing a stirgil towards his right arm that is found in the Vatican Museums.

Possibly a more famous statue of an athlete is this sculptor's Discobolus, which depicts a man about to throw a discus. Pliny the Elder claims that this artist made an extremely-realistic sculpture of a cow.
The Kleophrades painter depicted this goddess on the opposite side of a vase that depicts two athletes kickboxing. Phidias created a gigantic statue of this goddess for the Parthenon.

answers: Sweden [or Kingdom of Sweden; or Konungariket Sverige] (The former author is Stig Dagerman.)
parts: Name this country whose literary Nine Society included Karin Boye ("KAH-rin BOH-yuh"), who wrote the dystopian novel Kallocain.
This playwright of The Ghost Sonata and Miss Julie names a prize awarded since 1989 to the best Swedish works of literature.
This Swedish author of Gösta Berling's Saga was the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in Literature and later the first female member of the Swedish Academy.

answers: topoisomerases [accept type I topoisomerases or type II topoisomerases or DNA gyrases]
parts: Name this treatment regimen which uses cytotoxic chemicals called "antineoplastic agents" to kill cells. Much like radiation therapy, this procedure can result in hair loss.

Vinca alkaloid chemotherapy drugs act by binding to this protein. Heterodimers of the alpha and beta forms of this protein are polymerized to form structures found in the axoneme and the mitotic spindle.
Irinotecan and doxorubicin are chemotherapy drugs that block the function of these enzymes. Quinolone antibiotics, like levofloxacin, also work by blocking these enzymes.
